I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional research and development technical assistance project was included in the 
2007  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department (RSDD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to undertake analytical work and 
support project formulation on issues related to the environmental management of cities and to 
support sustainable urban development in Asia.1 The TA is still included in the 2009 TA 
program of RSDD. Urban environmental infrastructure is a high priority under ADB’s long-term 
strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)2 and an important issue for developing member 
countries (DMCs). The public sector cannot meet the need alone. A closer partnership between 
the public and private sectors is thus essential. ADB can play a key role in helping to finance 
this need and foster partnerships between the public and private sectors. In addressing these 
issues, this TA responds to both the demands of DMCs and the operational needs of ADB. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
2.  Urban economies play a central role in Asia’s economic growth and development. 
Under ADB’s Strategy 2020,  ADB is committed to making Asia’s cities more livable. Crucial to 
this task is improving the urban environment. Infrastructure should be designed to mitigate 
environmental  impacts  through  reduced  waste  generation  and  resource  use  to  foster 
sustainability and an improved environment. The design of infrastructure determines patterns of 
resource use and waste generation for decades. It is thus essential that these designs be 
appropriate for a sustainable future. In line with this, regional and national institutions are 
required to improve the efficiency of current patterns of resource use. This may be done by 
applying the reduce, reuse, and recycle (3R) principles set out under the global 3R Initiative, 
which was agreed at the Sea Island Summit 2004 following on a proposal from the Government 
of Japan.3 ADB has contributed to the initiative, through, for instance, publishing the report 
Toward Resource Efficient Economies in Asia and the Pacific with the Institute for Global 
Environmental Strategies (IGES) and presenting it as an input to the Group of Eight summit in 
2008.4  It  has  become apparent  that  DMCs  regard  investing  in infrastructure  to  conserve 
resources and minimize waste generation as vital to improving the resource efficiency and 
sustainability of their economies.   
 
3.  Country experience in implementing the initiative has been extensive. In Viet Nam, the 
Project for Implementation Support for 3R Initiative in Hanoi City has been implemented with 
the Hanoi Urban Environment Company and the Hanoi Women’s Union Project. Its purpose is 
to prepare a harmonized 3R system based on a program of separating organic waste at the 
source throughout Hanoi. In the Philippines, the project for establishing an ecological solid 
waste–management system in three cities has been implemented in collaboration with the 
Government of the Philippines. In the People’s Republic of China, the project for promoting a 
recycling economy has been implemented from the perspective of environmental protection 
and strengthening the capacity of major players at each step in material recycling. In Indonesia,

the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  is  preparing  in  2009  a  technical  cooperation 
project to develop capacity in 3R promotion and domestic solid waste management with the 
Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Public Works. In the Fiji Islands, Japan International 
Cooperation Agency has initiated the Waste Reduction/Recycling Promotion Project with the 
Department of Environment in 2008. 
 
4.  This TA responds to both the demands of DMCs for the provision of sustainable city 
infrastructure and the regional need to develop investment models adapting 3R principles to 
specific  circumstances  in  each  participating  DMC.  Recently,  countries  and  development 
partners under the regional 3R Initiative, including ADB, agreed to establish a 3R regional 
forum aiming to promote policy dialogues and the implementation of 3R-oriented projects. This 
TA will enable ADB to support DMCs’ investment in such sectors as solid waste management, 
energy efficiency, and waste water treatment. However, such projects have been difficult to 
package, often requiring coordination across local government agencies. The TA will provide 
resources to address these issues prior to detailed project preparation and financing. 
 
5.  Such objectives are completely in line with ADB's Strategy 2020 (footnote 2). Strategy 
2020 sets out clear areas of focus in urban infrastructure related to climate change and livable 
cities  and  encourages  partnering  with  other  agencies.  These  objectives  are  met  in  many 
subsectors of urban infrastructure through policies fostered under the 3R Initiative. In addition, 
the initiative will enable ADB to increase the quantity and improve the quality of its urban 
lending based on the principles of sustainability. To this end, the TA will assist in project 
formulation for 3R projects, leverage cofinancing for longer-term programmatic interventions 
and thereby expand pipelines, and bolster urban sector knowledge and sector analysis, thereby 
improving project quality. It will support urban networking and outreach in 3R. 
 
6.  Through the TA, ADB has the opportunity to partner strongly with the private sector and 
bilateral  donors.  For  example,  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  and  German 
development cooperation through GTZ are participating in the 3R Initiative, supporting DMCs in 
capacity and institutional development and making some bilateral investments. The United 
Nations Center for Regional Development and the United Nations Environment Programme 
participate  in  the  3R  Initiative  and  assist  Bangladesh,  Cambodia,  Indonesia,  Philippines, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam in developing 3R national strategies, with support from ADB and the 
Ministry of the Environment, Japan. Coordination with such organizations will be done through 
networking under the 3R regional forum.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  This TA is one of a number of ADB responses to urbanization issues in Asia. The project 
follows on from the Managing the Cities in Asia TA,5 which proposed a number of responses to 
the issues raised in the Special Evaluation Study on Urban Sector Strategy and Operations.6 
These were (i) more effective support for ADB’s urban operations departments7 and the urban 
community of practice (urban CoP) and (ii) more effective partnerships. The current TA will 
                                                 
5  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Managing the Cities in Asia. Manila (TA 6293-REG, approved on 19 
December). 
6  ADB. 2006. Special Evaluation Study on Urban Sector Strategy and Operations. Manila. This rated the Urban 
Sector Strategy as relevant and effective but only partly efficient and less sustainable, mainly because of staffing 
and lending modality constraints on ADB urban operations. 
7  ADB’s regional departments and the Private Sector Operations Department.

3 
         
     
support the formulation of projects that respond to these issues. 
 
8.  Thus,  in  the  context  of  Strategy  2020,  this  TA  will  contribute  to  the  improved 
management of urban development in DMCs to achieve livable cities that are environmentally 
sustainable. It will foster new forms of project formulation and administration and increase 
support for operations departments’ urban operations.  
 
9.  The outcome of the TA will be increased investment in urban infrastructure to meet the 
needs of urban residents, providing better service with reduced adverse environmental impacts, 
and  an  increase  in  the  sustainability  of  cities  by  incorporating  3R  principles  in  waste 
management and other urban infrastructure investment.  
  
10.  To achieve these outcomes, the main activities of the TA are to (i) prepare projects 
and/or programs financeable by ADB for selected cities in the target countries that incorporate 
3R principles in urban management and (ii) collect, process, manage, and disseminate the 
knowledge captured in project formulation and other relevant activities under the 3R regional 
forum.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The two components of the project are as follows: 
 
(i)  Component 1: Project formulation. RSDD will make a pool of funds available 
to operations departments for formulating projects and/or programs financeable 
by ADB for selected cities that incorporate 3R principles in waste management, 
urban  transport,  urban  subsovereign  finance,  and  urban  economic  (cluster) 
development. The projects and/or programs will be identified and prioritized n 
close collaboration with operations departments based on the outputs of the 
knowledge  activities  of  the  urban  CoP,  relevant  project  identification  by 
operations departments, and inputs from the 3R regional forum.  Once projects 
and/or programs are selected, suitable consultants will be engaged for each to 
meet  their  specific  needs.  These  consultants  will  be  engaged  by  RSDD  in 
consultation with operations departments. RSDD will manage the consultants in 
close collaboration with the clients and operations departments as they conduct 
pre-feasibility studies and initial implementation activities, etc. The urban CoP 
will have a key role in providing guidance to consultants. Priority will be given to 
public-private partnership projects. A local consultant will be engaged to help 
RSDD to manage TA activities. 
 
(ii)  Component  2:  Regional  knowledge  sharing.  RSDD  will  collect,  process, 
manage, and disseminate the knowledge captured in component 1 and other 
activities under the 3R regional forum. Consultants will be engaged to assist 
RSDD  in  these  activities.  Institutions  already  engaged  in  the  3R  Initiative 
through the 3R knowledge hub—jointly hosted by Asian Institute Technology 
(AIT) and the United Nations Environment Programme and established under 
TA for the Establishment of Regional Knowledge Hubs8—will be engaged for 
specific studies. A particular focus of this component will be on adapting the

approved on 21 December).

various  models  of  3R  investments  for  city  development  to  the  specific 
circumstances of participating in DMCs. Analytical studies will be selectively 
conducted regionally, subregionally, or nationally in collaboration with partners in 
the 3R regional forum. To disseminate the knowledge to and through operations 
departments, the urban CoP will participate in and selectively initiate various 
events such as workshops, seminars, and meetings of the 3R regional forum. 
This component will provide the urban CoP with resources to better manage 
knowledge in respect of 3R in ADB. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $2,000,000. The TA will be financed as a grant by the 
Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The TA cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, with its RSDD as the nodal department for 
implementation. RSDD will undertake TA activities in collaboration with relevant operations 
departments. A no-objection letter from the relevant DMCs will be obtained before commencing 
any activities in the territory of said DMC. The TA implementation team will comprise a team 
leader from RSDD supported by a subcommittee of the urban CoP. Implementation will take 
place over 24 months from December 2009. For both components, ADB will engage consultants 
in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
14.  Implementing  component  1  of  the  TA  will  require  about  40  person-months  of 
international consultancy and 60 person-months of national consultancy, contracted using the 
consultants’ qualification selection or single source selection, as appropriate.9 This modality is 
appropriate as the projects in this component are to be chosen during implementation through 
consultation between the urban CoP and governments. As such, flexibility in team formation is 
required.  The  projects  will  typically  be  undertaken  by  small  teams  of  consultants  highly 
specialized  in  the  sector  and  country.  The  project  formulation  consultants  will  undertake 
technical studies and specialized analytical studies under the guidance of the urban CoP and 
the supervision of operations departments. Operations departments will use the established 
one-page application format for urban CoP support, to be approved at monthly meetings. The 
terms  of  reference  and  project  formulation  milestones  will  be  determined  by  operations 
department supervising offices. 
 
15.  Implementing component 2 of the TA will require two streams: technical inputs to the 
initiative and the operation of the knowledge hub. The first stream of technical inputs will require 
about  6  person-months  of  international  consultancy  and  20  person-months  of  national 
consultancy.  It  is  proposed  that  IGES  be  contracted  on  a  single-source  basis  to  provide 
specialized analytical inputs related to 3R, as it has been the core institution providing technical 
inputs to the 3R Initiative in the past and is currently the focal point for research under the 3R 
                                                 
9  Consultants’ qualifications selection method may be used for small assignments where highly specialized expertise 
is required for the assignment and recruitment of “boutique” consulting firms that provide depth of expertise in 
specific areas is contemplated. Single source selection, indicatively, half will be by cost and quality selection, which 
is the preferred method if the assignment requires joint efforts from various experts. Where a competitive tender 
among firms qualified for the assignment is not possible, the consultants will be engaged through individual 
consultant selection.

5 
         
     
3R regional forum. IGES is proposed as the implementing agency for this component of the TA 
for the following reasons: 
 
(i)  IGES is an established leader in research and policy development in the 3R field 
and strongly supported by the Government of Japan as an environmental think 
tank, providing expert analysis and advice on all aspects of long- and short-term 
government policies and practice in the 3R field. 
 
(ii)  It  has  significant  experience  in  establishing  3R  networks  and  organizing 
international fora. In particular, IGES provides support to the development of the 
3R regional forum, including working with DMCs such as Viet Nam to prepare 
and implement 3R policies, including methodologies and systems.   
 
(iii)  IGES has been actively engaged in capacity development and the dissemination 
of knowledge related to 3R.  It has organized many workshops, conferences, and 
seminars and has a network for this with many organizations and professionals in 
DMCs. It is therefore in a better position to address the need to attract the 
participatory sharing of experiences from other countries through the 3R regional 
forum. 
 
16.  The second stream will require approximately 18 months of national consultancy and 
support  to  develop  knowledge  systems  and  capacity  development  toward  operating  the 
knowledge hub. IGES will focus on the research and knowledge development aspects of this 
stream and AIT will focus on the development of knowledge dissemination systems through 
their existing 3R knowledge hub. Thus, it is also proposed that AIT be contracted on a single-
source basis to provide knowledge hub services. AIT has been the knowledge hub for the 3R 
Initiative since July 2006 and has performed this task well to date. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for Project Preparation Support for 
Livable Cities in Asia.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) Project Preparation Support for Livable Cities in Asia will 
require inputs from international and national consultants drawn from a range of areas of 
expertise, institutions, and organizations. The consultants will include urban and infrastructure 
experts in planning, energy, transport, water supply and sanitation, environment, municipal 
management,  urban  finance,  and  urban  economics.  The  national  consultants  will  provide 
technical and research assistance support for the TA implementation team and should have 
strong background and experience in data collection and analysis, as well as practice in the 
areas listed above. A small secretariat will manage the TA and respond to requests from 
operations  departments.  Other  consultants  will  be  engaged  on  short-term  assignments  as 
required by operations departments. The detailed terms of reference for the consultants and 
their engagement periods will be finalized based on requests from operations departments in 
consultation with the managing task force during the implementation of the TA. 
 
B.  Consultants 
 
1.  Component 1: Project Formulation 
a.  Urban  and  Infrastructure  Consultants  (international,  40  person-
months) 
2.  The tasks of the urban and infrastructure consultants will be to (i) undertake research in 
waste  management,  urban  transport,  cluster  development,  and  municipal  finance  and 
(ii) support the operations of operations departments and analyze the impact of that support. 
This analysis will provide support to the urban community of practice of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) and to establishing a partnership facility for the sector, which will fund enhanced 
urban operations. The consultants must be capable of designing new modalities of support and 
innovative solutions, particularly in the areas of urban finance, energy, transport, water supply 
and sanitation, environment, and municipal management. This will require knowledge of existing 
literature  and  ongoing  work  within  and  outside  ADB,  analysis  of  trends  and  issues,  the 
identification of good practices and innovative approaches, and the ability to make suggestions 
about how to more effectively deliver support in the urban sector. The general approach will be 
to (i) provide consulting support to the development of sector strategies and projects as required 
by operations departments, (ii) analyze the existing situation of the urban sector in ADB DMCs, 
(iii) analyze trends in the region, and (iv) use the experiences of developing and developed 
countries to draw lessons for the sector. Consultants will be recruited as individuals, as set out 
in ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
b.  Urban and Infrastructure Consultants (national, 60 person-months) 
3.  The main task of the national consultants will be to provide high-quality assistance and 
inputs for the international consultants, backed where needed by strong data analysis. The 
tasks  of  the  national  consultants  will  include  (i)  supporting  the  activities  of  international 
consultants  in  the  field,  (ii)  reviewing  documents  and  literature,  (iii)  collecting  data  and 
information, (iv) quantitative and qualitative research and analysis, and (v) preparing notes and 
briefs. The national consultants will provide technical and administrative support to the TA 
implementation team until project completion. The national consultants will coordinate with 
national governments, other donors, and other ADB projects as needed. National consultants

responsibilities as required by the TA task force. Consultants will be recruited as individual

2.  Component 2: Regional Knowledge Sharing 
4.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks in support of (i) reduce, reuse and 
recycle (3R) regional forum projects to be identified under the 3R regional forum as part of its 
immediate activities, (ii) organizing regional training seminars, and (iii) knowledge-sharing using 
the  3R  knowledge  hub.  Tasks  (i)  and  (ii)  will  be  undertaken  by  the  Institute  for  Global 
Environmental Strategies (IGES) and task (iii) by the Asian Institute of Technology (AIT). 
5.  3R regional forum projects will be implemented by IGES and will require 6 months of 
international  consultancy  and  20  months  of  national  consultancy.  Consultants  will  produce 
knowledge on 3R issues to be shared across the region. 
 
(i)  Several  3R  regional  forum  projects  will  be  identified  and  selected  through 
consultation among ADB; Ministry of Environment, Japan; IGES; and United 
Nations Center for Regional Development, based on the discussion in the 3R 
regional forum and its preparatory process, as well as other information. This will 
be done in due course but not later than December 2009. 
 
(ii)  The  project  normally  entails  analytical  studies  but  may  include  a  small  pilot 
intervention component if the cost is borne by a counterpart and it is a necessary 
part  of  the  study.  It  may  include  capacity-building  or  awareness-building 
components if their outputs are useful for participating countries. 
 
(iii)  Consultants for the project may be selected from a range of local specialists, 
local consultants, local or international staff of nongovernment organizations, and 
researchers and staff in research institutes or other capable entities, depending 
on requirements. 
 
(iv)  Analytical studies do not necessarily have linkages with component 1 projects, 
but they may provide good opportunities to learn important lessons on planning 
and practice. 
 
6.  Regional training seminars will be organized. 
 
(i)  Under this subcomponent, two meetings and stakeholder consultations will be 
carried out to disseminate knowledge captured from stakeholders. The purpose, 
modality, and target audience will be determined in the implementation stage. 
 
(ii)  The  meetings  are  likely  to  include  (a)  a  consultation  meeting  necessary  for 
planning  component  1,  (b)  a  regional  and/or  subregional  meeting  to  share 
knowledge created by the analytical studies under the component 2, and (c) a 
side event of the 3R regional forum to share the output of the TA.

(iii)  Indicative budgets for these activities are $20,000 each for the training program 
and stakeholder consultation. 
 
7.  Knowledge-sharing and dissemination using the 3R knowledge hub at AIT will require 18 
months of local consultant input and will encompass the following: 
 
(i)  The  knowledge-sharing  activities  of  3R  knowledge  hub will  be  supported  by 
financing basic services provided by the 3R knowledge hub that are essential to 
the maintenance of the 3R Initiative. Implemented activities will be defined in a 
new  work  plan  that  will  be  developed  by  the  3R  knowledge  hub  in  close 
consultation with key partners (ADB; the Ministry of Environment, Japan; IGES; 
United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific; and 
United Nations Center for Regional Development). 
 
(ii)  The support budget for 3R knowledge hub will, indicatively, fund (a) $45,000 for 
AIT personnel; (b) $30,000 for travel for 3R knowledge hub activities; (c) $20,000 
for  information  technology  facilities  (webhosting);  (d)  $45,000  for  resource 
persons and experts; (e) $15,000 for capacity building; (f) $40,000 for rent and 
utilities, etc.; and (g) $5,000 for miscellaneous and reporting costs. 
 
(iii)  The  services  of  the  3R  knowledge  hub  include  web-based  and  published 
documentation of best practice and lessons learned in implementing 3R activities.
